newsitem.title: ITALY: Reuters Asset Allocation Poll (Italy) - January 13.
newsitem.headline: Reuters Asset Allocation Poll (Italy) - January 13.

text.p: Italian banks and investment funds are less enthusiastic on Italy's debt market as bond yields have fallen and are seeking alternative ways to diversify their investments, an Italian Reuters Asset Allocation Poll showed on Monday.

Major Italian banks and fund managers contacted for the January poll had a more neutral stance towards the domestic bond market than in December's survey. The next poll will be published in the first week of February.

"Prospects for the Italian bond market, which in 1996 rose a lot, are more limited this year. Bond yields last year fell a lot and the market conditions both in terms of yields and in terms of capital gains, do not justify such a strong preference for this type of investments," said Carlo Capotorti, head of the research department at Centrosim.
Credito Italiano, which uses a three-month timeframe rather than a monthly one, recommends underweighting Italian fixed-rate bonds and investing in Italian short- and medium- term bonds.

"Italy's difficulty in reaching the 3.0-percent deficit/GDP target in 1997, which will be highlightened in the quarterly report on state accounts, along with the end of convergence trades combined with a general weakness of the lira, suggests we should stay underweight in Italian bonds, especially in the fixed-rate sector," Credito Italiano said in a note. The bank recommends investing 34 percent of a total Italian bond portfolio in floating rate CCT certificates.

Analysts polled agreed investors should diversify into equities and said thatt among these, Europe and Italy have the most to gain while Wall Street, which has already reached record highs, has more limited scope for growth.
